roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the case is submitted We'll hear argument next in Number oh oh ten seventy-two, Leonard Edelman versus Lynchburg College.
Mr. Schnapper.
[Inaudible]
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

The relation-back rule for verification under section sixteen oh one point twelve B is a proper exercise of the authority granted to the EEOC under section seven thirteen of title seven to promulgate procedural regulations.
The regulation is consistent with the language of section seven oh six.
Title seven requires that a charge be verified, and the statute also requires that a charge be filed within a hundred and eighty or three hundred days of the act of discrimination.
But as Judge Luttig correctly observed below, these two statutory requirements are independent of each other.
Specifically, section seven oh six E one establishes deadlines of a hundred and eighty or three hundred days, but it applies those deadlines only to when, quote, a charge must be filed.
Section seven oh six E one does not purport to establish a deadline for verification.
Conversely, section seven oh six B requires verification, but it contains no deadline for doing so.
That omission is particularly significant because other requirements which are contained in section seven oh six B do have deadlines.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What what about the other elements that that that have that that are required by the statute to be in the in the cla- in the charge? Surely the commission has to serve notice of the charge, including the date, place and circumstances of the alleged unlawful employment practice.
Isn't that statutory provision implicitly a requirement that the charge contain the date, place, and circumstances of the alleged unlawful practice?
O- I wouldn't go quite that far.

The the the commission's interpretation of that, which is embodied in section sixteen oh one point twelve B, concludes that a charge is sufficient if it identifies the parties and contains a description of the alleged discriminatory practice.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, how how can how can the statute be complied with? I mean, the statute, two thousand E dash five B, clearly says that the commission on receiving a charge shall serve a notice of it, paren, including the date, place, and circumstances of the alleged unlawful employment practice...
Well, it does...
on the employer.
it does so provide.
So, you you think the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: charge doesn't even have to e- c- because the commission hasn't chosen to require that, a charge doesn't even have to contain the date, circumstances, and place of the alleged we-
Well, the commission has...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What does it have to contain?
The regulation...
I have...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: been discriminated against?
It I I understand the regulation to require more specificity than that.
No. I understand that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But but what you say about about the requirement or or nonrequirement of of of of of of oath, of of it being under oath, I think you you you're going to have to logically say about other requirements or, a- a- a- as you think them, nonrequirements of the charge.
I I think that you have to read well, the com- the commission's view is that there is a- a- an irreducible minimum that has to be in a charge.
Why?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why does it come to that position? It just made it up?
The statute expressly provides that the commission can specify what information needs to be in a charge, and that's the...
I see. Not...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: because there's any statutory compulsion, but just in its in its wisdom and beneficence, the commission has decided that there has to be a certain minimal amount of information in the charge,
I I I I don't know f- f-
Federal Register recounts any any explanation, but I- it seems to me it would be logical for the commission to have looked at that the provision to which you refer in in in framing the...
the requirements it has.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: provision to which I refer, it would say a charge has to I'm, we're not going to bother an employer and require him to come back with a response unless y- you you haven't just come in and said, I've been discriminated against.
Well, w- w- what happens as a practical matter where verification occurs after the filing date is that the employer is usually not required to actually take any action.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But here what the employer wasn't even no- wasn't notified until the form on the EEOC's proper form that did everything, including the verification.

Your Honor, i- it's our view that the that the court of that the EEOC erred in not providing notice at that time, and it's I think it's clear, from a reading of the compliance manual, that its own manual did require notice at that time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And and would also require notice of of of of a charge that was imperfect in other respects within ten days of receiving the charge.
If you...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: a telephone in the the requirement that it be in writing, for example, that's a requirement the that isn't isn't particularly in the in the statute of limitations provision, but it's a requirement that it be in writing.
The...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: contact the employer about that.
The it's our view that that that if the commission receives a sufficient charge, it must do so.
This is all...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: just a matter of the regulations.
The the the statute requires that a charge be filed, so I think it would have to be reduced to writing.
But I, but I was saying...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: filed.
But I would say the...
commission probably could alter its its its regulation and deem a memorialized phone call the filing of the charge.
here.

And and to to get back to the specific issue before the Court, the Fifth Circuit excuse me the Fourth Circuit would have reached the same result in this case regardless of whether this letter, notice of this letter or the letter itself had been served on the employer within ten days of the receipt of the letter on November fourteenth.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

Yes.
It remains...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: those four questions are alive and would have to be...
It it th- it remains open to the to the respondent to raise those issues on remand, and and we think that that's the appropriate procedure...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
f- for addressing it.
Do you do you think it's...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: good practice for the EEOC to wait until after the three hundred day period and a verification before it even notifies...
No.
No, they, it was in in our view, it was improper to have done that here, that that the the the statute doesn't authorize them to await verification.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
does identify some circumstances in which there might be delay in in in notification.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Let me suppose you have a statutory provision which says that the complaint shall be in writing, sworn to under oath, shall set forth the time, place, and circumstances of the alleged grievance, comma, and shall be presented to the agency within one hundred days after the alleged grievance.
Yes.
Yes.
I I...

text_blocks.text: any boy, I would never read a statute that way.
I don't, well...

text_blocks.text: that that that that go that far?
The the Federal rules require that a notice of appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed within a certain period of time.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

No.
which requires an answer within so many days. It's simply a heads-up.

Well, that's not fo-

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you you s- you you you you want us to accept this argument as to what a charge is, but then you don't want us to accept it for when the employer has to know about it so the evidence doesn't go stale.

It's not that the it's not that the agency is waiting for verification before it gives notice, and if the only thing missing from a charge is verification, the agency's procedures require notice within ten days.
Well, but...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: aren't, shouldn't the two be be tied together? I mean, it's reasonable to have it relate back so long as there is no prejudice to the to the employer from having it relate back.

The...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that's a separate mistake, and whatever prejudice comes from that the employer is free to raise on remand.

to the employer.
absolutely.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What about the argument that B comes before E, so and to define what a charge is, the word charge, and then i- it's given a certain description in B.
Well, title seven didn't define the word charge as a verified charge.
And in the normal...
course of business, the agency will try to obtain a standard form whose signature line contains an affirmation, and so the verification requirement will be supplied.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: C- Can you tell me what happens, j- it's not this case if there's a rule in the in the circuits, I don't think we passed on it.
Yeah, we know of just a handful of cases where the charge just got lost in the system, and w- the consequences of that would turn on two factors.

O- Justice Ginsburg, we don't believe that that is a permissible reading of the statute.
There's simply no...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that the reading that you are saying is the only proper reading is s- somewhat inconsistent with this Court's position in Becker against Montgomery last t- term.

Justice Ginsburg, we we don't think so because we think what happened in Becker was a a a harmonization of two rules of the Court, with a focus particularly on rule eleven, which in the same rule which established the requirement of the of the signing, established the the method to cure a failure to sign.
I think we we heard...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the argument from Mr. Schnapper and Miss Blatt that as a background common law principle, the the idea of a curative amendment to provide a signature, to provide verification that then relates back is nothing new.

Your Honor, I I believe that the background principle, if you will, the background legal principle of our federalism and the background legal principle of due process to employers in fairness to employers in giving notice, was probably more a part of the applicable legal background here...
But that was conceded, the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But that's not what anybody is urging here.
Well, Your Honor, there wa- the the letter itself was never verified.
There was a form five that was verified.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: like an amended complaint.
There's no indication that Congress here adopted common law pleading rules.
Do you question,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Bell, your opponents' descriptions of the common law pleading background that a complaint that was f- s- s- was required by rule to be verified filed not verified could be verified later?
There are certainly many cases that hold that.
put out.

text_blocks.text: may I ask, that , going back to Justice Scalia's questions e- earlier? The statute requires that the charges shall be in writing, under oath or ath- affirmation, and shall contain such information and and be in such form as the commission requires.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

Any any little any little foot fault...

that...

rules required.
by the commission, I think that's what the statute says.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

But you...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What was filed in the court of appeals within the time that you had to file the notice lacked a signature.
Yes...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: thing that's here within the thirty, three hundred days.

Well, w- we see a fundamental difference between this Court harmonizing rules over which this Court has control, and the Court deciding whether to apply requirements set out in a statute that Congress used to create a certain right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You're you're not asserting that our reading of our own rules is unreasonable, are you?
No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, but if our reading of our rules isn't unreasonable and this agency has simply read the statute the way we read our rules, then I assume that this agency's reading of the statute is not unreasonable.
Your Honor, I, there are two reason we don't think Chevron is the correct, Chevron would uphold this regulation.
that's embodied in the statute.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the Government has asserted that that's not the case, and I'm a I, if that if, I I I think we we we have to accept that unless you have solid evidence to the contrary that that in fact they think the notice is normally given and should have been given when here when the when the charge was received...
They have said that today.
I I and I...
of course saw their...

for sure that it's not.

Well, a- again, I I refer the Court to the Government's brief in support of amicus , o- of of of, sorry of granting the writ, pages o- sixteen and seventeen.
Mr. Bell, a lawyer...

I I understand.

Yes, Justice Ginsburg.

Well, that same...

text_blocks.text: the f- the same formal whatever they called it, form X, wh- when it was sent to the employer was also sent to the State agency.

I- Is it...

I, I see that...

that in...

If e- e- e-

interesting...

and this of course, this regulation was not passed with notice and comment rulemaking either, which under the Mead decision gives it less weight than it might have if i- if the regulation...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought the Congress authorized the EEOC to make procedural rules, didn't it?
They did.

By other proof e- Your Honor, I suppose w- w- we lawyers could differ on whether it's a procedural or substantive rule.
Well, what would you call rule fifteen C of the Federal Rules of Civil...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

fifteen...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that a rule of procedure? The relation-back rule?
, I, Yes, Your Honor, it is.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I'm I'm not sure that Mead does does, I don't un-, does does Mead say that that even rules adopted without notice and comment are entitled to Chevron deference so long as they were authorized? I mean, I thought all rules had to be authorized whether whether they do notice and comment or not.
Well,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: starting point, isn't it?
and one of the problems with this rule is that there's no delegation of authority to the agency to define the term charge, which is, in essence, what they've done.
But how would you distinguish...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: from the point of view of the claimant who is filing the original charge, sends a letter, as here, and then the EEOC, if it were super-efficient, would have gotten out the the form in good time?
It did in this case, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: How many days did he have left?
He had it for approximately a month, at least three weeks.
Thank you, Mr. Bell.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Schnapper, you have five minutes remaining.
Thank you, Your Honor.
non ver-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: manual say about verification, later verification?
I don't believe the manual addresses it.
when service is to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: one might infer that then that l- post-filing verification i- is not authorized.
It's expressly authorized by the regulation in this case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Schnapper.
The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at ten o'clock.
